content:
Many thanks for referring [redacted name] who I reviewed today with her daughter present. She has unfortunately experienced disease progression on her current chemotherapy regimen for metastatic triple negative breast cancer. Originally diagnosed with left breast cancer in January 2024, initially presenting as a 6.5cm mass with axillary nodal involvement. Histology confirmed grade 3 metaplastic matrix-producing carcinoma, triple negative with PDL1 90%. Staging investigations revealed widespread metastatic disease affecting lungs, liver, and bones including T7 vertebral body.

Initial treatment with carboplatin/gemcitabine/pembrolizumab was commenced in February 2024 but discontinued after 2 cycles due to grade 3 neutropenia despite GCSF support. Treatment was changed to weekly paclitaxel with continued pembrolizumab, which she received for 6 weeks until recent admission with increasing breathlessness.

CT chest performed during admission shows significant progression with increase in pulmonary metastases, new pleural effusions, and enlarging liver lesions. Her performance status has deteriorated to ECOG 3, now spending most of the day in bed. She requires oxygen 3L/min at rest and has increasing right upper quadrant pain requiring oxycodone 20mg 4-hourly.

On examination today, she appears cachectic with obvious breathlessness at rest. Chest examination reveals reduced air entry bilaterally with dullness to percussion at both bases. The liver edge is palpable 4cm below the costal margin and tender. The left breast mass is unchanged clinically at 8cm.

Given her rapid disease progression and declining performance status, I have had a detailed discussion with [redacted name] and her daughter about moving to a palliative approach. We have arranged urgent referral to the palliative care team for symptom management and community support. She will be reviewed by the pleural team tomorrow regarding therapeutic aspiration of effusions. I have prescribed additional breakthrough analgesia and anti-emetics, and arranged weekly review through our enhanced supportive care clinic.

primary_cancer.metastases: widespread metastatic disease affecting lungs, liver, and bones including T7 vertebral body

cancer_timeline.value: Discontinued carboplatin/gemcitabine/pembrolizumab after 2 cycles due to grade 3 neutropenia despite GCSF support
Changed to weekly paclitaxel with continued pembrolizumab
CT shows progression with increase in pulmonary metastases, new pleural effusions, and enlarging liver lesions

patient_facts.value: ECOG 3, spending most of the day in bed
Increasing right upper quadrant pain requiring oxycodone 20mg 4-hourly
Cachectic with obvious breathlessness at rest
Reduced air entry bilaterally with dullness to percussion at both bases
Liver edge palpable 4cm below costal margin and tender
Left breast mass unchanged clinically at 8cm

status_updates.value: Metastatic triple negative breast cancer with rapid progression through two lines of systemic therapy. Significant clinical deterioration with symptomatic progression in lungs and liver
Disease progression on imaging with increasing pulmonary metastases, new pleural effusions, and enlarging liver lesions
Deterioration to ECOG PS 3 with increasing oxygen requirements and pain
Urgent referral to palliative care team and pleural team, weekly review in enhanced supportive care clinic
